section.title: Introduction
section.para: For complete installation instructions see .
SCIRun is officially compatible with two platforms, SGI and Linux.
&sr; may be installed from RPMs (for Mandrake 9 and Red Hat 8 systems only) or from source code tarballs (for Linux and SGI).

section.title: Introduction
section.para: You must have root privileges to install &sr;. Ask your system administrator to perform in installation if you don't have access to the superuser account.
The following procedure installs &sr; in /usr/local/SCIRun/bin.

RPM installation consists of the following steps:
Downloading the &sr; rpm distribution.
Installing &sr; using the rpm command.
Installing &sr;'s sample data sets.
See after installing but before starting &sr;

section.title: Downloading &sr;'s RPM
section.para: Obtain the appropriate &sr; rpm, either SCIRun-x.x.x-mdk9.0.i586.rpm for Mandrake 9 systems or or SCIRun-x.x.x-rh8.0.i386.rpm for Redhad 8 systems. Be sure to get DataSets.x.x.x.tar.gz too. These files can be downloaded from SCI's software archive page.

section.title: Installing &sr;
section.para:
As superuser cd to the directory where &sr; was downloaded and type:
rpm -ivh SCIRun-x.x.x-mdk9.0.i586.rpm
or
rpm -ivh SCIRun-x.x.x-rh8.0.i386.rpm
Type exit to leave the root account.
See before starting &sr;

section.title: Installing &sr;'s Sample Data Sets
section.para:
Unpack &sr;'s sample data sets in /usr/local/SCIRun. Become root and type
gunzip -c DataSets.x.x.x.tar.gz | \ (cd /usr/local/SCIRun && tar xf -)
This will create /usr/local/SCIRun/SCIRunData, the sample data sets directory.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: Python (version 1.5.2 or later) and GNU make (version 3.79 or later) must be present before proceeding with the tarball installation.

Installation from tarballs consists of these steps:
Downloading (compressed) tarballs containing &sr; sources, packages, third party software, and sample data sets.
Unpacking the tarballs.
Building and installing third party software.
Building &sr;
See before starting &sr;

note.para:
If you are building &sr; for the Itanium architecture you must use the GNU compiler collection (gcc). And you must set the values of the environment variables CFLAGS and CXXFFLAGS as follows before building &sr; and its third party libraries:
setenv CFLAGS fPIC setenv CXXFLAGS fPIC
for csh-type shells or
CFLAGS=fPIC CXXFLAGS=fPIC export CFLAGS CXXFLAGS
for sh-type shells,

section.title: Downloading
section.para: Obtain the source code for SCIRun and any desired packages. Be sure to get the Thirdparty_install.x.x.x.tar.gz and DataSets.x.x.x.tar.gz files too. The compressed tarballs for these sources can be downloaded from SCI's software archive page.

listitem.para:
Unpack the SCIRun tarball:
gunzip -c SCIRun.x.x.x.tar.gz | tar xf -
This will create a directory called SCIRun.

Unpack the compressed package tarballs into SCIRun/src/Packages, for example:
gunzip -c BioPSE.PKG.x.x.x.tar.gz | (cd SCIRun/src/Packages && tar xf -)
to unpack the BioPSE package.

Unpack the tarball containing sample datasets:
gunzip -c DataSets.x.x.x.tar.gz | tar xf -
This will create the directory SCIRunData.

Unpack the third party tarball:
gunzip -c Thirdparty_install.x.x.x.tar.gz | tar xf -
This will create the directory Thirdparty_install.x.x.x.

cd to the third party software directory:
cd Thirdparty_install.x.x.x
Run the third party installation script.

The simplest invocation of the script looks like this:
python install dir
where dir is the directory under which the third-party software will be installed. For example:
python install /usr/local/&sr;/Third_Party

The script may also be invoked as follows:
python install dir bits jobs
where dir is the directory under which the third-party software will be installed, bits is one of 32 or 64 and specifies either 32 bit or 64 bit binaries, and jobs is the number of process that make will use when building the software. For example:
python install /usr/local/&sr;/Third_Party 64 2
or
python install /usr/local/&sr;/Third_Party 32 1
When finished, the installation script will display the complete path name of the third-party software installation directory—make note of this value.

section.title: Building SCIRun

listitem.para:
Run SCIRun's configure script. Do this from a sub-directory of &sr; (but not &sr;/src) as follows:
mkdir SCIRun/dir cd SCIRun/dir ../src/configure --with-thirdparty=third-party-dir \ --enable-package="package-name1 package-name2 …"
&sr; will be built in the directory &sr;/dir. Above, third-party-dir is replaced by the name of the third party software installation directory and "package-name1 package-name2 …" is replaced by a list of (previously downloaded and unpacked) package names , e.g. "BioPSE MatlabInterface". For example:
../src/configure \ --with-thirdparty=/usr/local/SCIRun_Third_Party/1.4.2/Irix/CC-32bit \ --enable-package="BioPSE"

Run (GNU) make (from the directory used previously when running configure):
make
or
make -j N
if your machine has N available processors. This will produce a scirun executable.

section.para: See before starting &sr;

section.title: Preparing &sr;
section.para:
Before starting &sr; you should initialize 2 environment variables:
SCIRUN_ON_THE_FLY_LIBS_DIR
Each &sr; user should create an on the fly directory (see for details):
mkdir ~/&sr;_otf
Then, before executing &sr; each user must set the environment variable SCIRUN_ON_THE_FLY_LIBS_DIR to point to ~/&sr;_otf:
export SCIRUN_ON_THE_FLY_LIBS_DIR=~/&sr;_otf
for Bourne-type shells, and
setenv SCIRUN_ON_THE_FLY_LIBS_DIR ~/&sr;_otf
for C shell-type shells. Alternatively, users may create the file ~/.scirunrc with the following content:
SCIRUN_ON_THE_FLY_LIBS_DIR=/path/to/&sr;_otf
SCIRUN_DATA
It specifies the default data directory of &sr; data sets. If you will be working through the &sr; tutorial then you will want to set it to point to the sample data sets directory:
export SCIRUN_DATA=/path/to/SCIRunData
or
setenv SCIRUN_DATA /path/to/SCIRunData

section.title: Starting &sr;
section.para: Before starting &sr; read
If you installed &sr; from it's rpm you can test it's installation by typing /usr/local/SCIRun/bin/scirun.
If you built &sr; from it's source code tarballs then you can test it's installation by cding to it's build directory and typing ./scirun.
After starting &sr; you should see it's network editor window and the &sr; shell prompt. See if problems occur.
